original: Hallgren, Rolf Johan Mattias, förste provinsialläkare, Göteborg, f. 4/5/93 i Malmö av civ :ing. Johan Olof H.’ o. Matilda Amöna Berner. G. 1. 17-35 m. tandlli Tora Månsson ; 2. 36 m. Hobbies: lång-s^egl. o. n’av’i(g:öiversiättn. t. eng. RNO.
translated: Hallgren, Rolf Johan Mattias, first provincial physician, Gothenburg, born on May 4, 1893 in Malmö to civil engineer Johan Olof H. and Matilda Amöna Berner. Married (1) in 1917 to dental assistant Tora Månsson, and (2) in 1936 to Asta Hallqvist. Children: Susanne (born 1924, student), Rut-Marie (born 1925, student), John (born 1932, student), Carin (born 1944), and Per (born 1945). He passed the matriculation exam in Malmö in 1911, earned his Bachelor of Medicine in 1916, his doctoral degree in medicine in 1921, and his doctor of medicine in 1943; all from Lund University. He studied abroad in Munich in 1921, and in Great Britain and Geneva in 1929. He was appointed as an assistant physician and then as the first and second doctor to Kirurgiska Kliniken, Ortopediska kliniken, Öronkliniken and Kvinnokliniken at Lund University Hospital for two years from 1918 to 1922. He was appointed as the district physician in Hälleviksstrand and dispensary physician from 1923 to 1930, temporary second medical officer in Kirurgiska kliniken at Helsingborg Hospital in 1925, temporary assistant physician at Gothenburg's Epidemic Hospital in 1930, first assistant physician to Kirurgiska kliniken at Uddevalla Hospital from 1930 to 1933, temporary hospital physician there for four months, temporary first provincial physician in Jämtland in 1933, obstetrician at Gothenburg's Maternity Hospital from 1933 to 1934, practicing physician in Gothenburg from 1934 to 1935 and again from 1943, temporary hospital physician in Kisa in 1936, provincial physician in Lysekil's district in 1936–1938, first provincial physician in Västerbotten from 1938 to 1943, and first provincial physician in Gothenburg and Bohuslän since 1943. He became the head of the medical department at the Health Board in 1943, a lecturer in health care at the Navigation School in Gothenburg since 1944, and a lecturer in social institutions in Gothenburg since 1944. He has published several secure principal topics in epidemiology. His hobbies include long sailing trips and translating to English. He is also a member of the Royal Order of the Northern Star.
